newsitem.title: UK: London precious metals seen in narrow range.
newsitem.headline: London precious metals seen in narrow range.

text.p: Precious metals prices were forecast to move in fairly narrow ranges on Tuesday but dealers warned that last week's volatility could return.
"It's been quiet yesterday and today but the volatility will return although it may take a couple of days," one dealer said.
Gold was fixed at $361.75 per ounce following $362.15 on Monday afternoon having received little impetus since the close.

New York spot closed lower at $361.70/$362.20 after gold and silver hit early highs and Tokyo and Hong Kong finished just above the U.S. closing figure influenced by the weaker yen, short covering and late profittaking.
Testimony from U.S. federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan was expected to cover issues touched last week, dealers said.
Continuing fund short covering looked like the best chance gold had to climb through the $360s, dealers said.
Since bullion bottomed at its 3-3/4 year low on February 12 at $336.90 it has climbed to within $5.00 of its opening year level (the Jan 2 fix was $367.80, the 1997 high to date).
Meanwhile Comex's "large trader" net short positions fell to 21,241 contracts by February 25 from 46,650 two weeks earlier, according to Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
"Fund short covering will dominate the market. The producers may see the rise and sell into it so we could have a volatile price," one dealer said.
Nevertheless the fund-driven momentum could take gold prices through the $370s, the dealer said.
Meanwhile gold was seen in a $358.00-$364.00 with physical support holding the downside.
Silver was largely ignored at $5.28/$5.30 having seen most of its action late on Monday in New York when it was bought up to about $5.40 and promptly sold into.
On Monday the gold-silver ratio was about 68 having gone from 65 to 70 mid February before being sold off.
"If it goes below 64, it could be heading for 57.30," said technical analyst Karen Jones at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Palladium was steady at $150.00/$151.00, $4.50 down on Monday's close which was inflated by a brief bought of buying.
"Palladium is probably supporting the whole complex," one dealer said.
Mixed reports on the severity and impact of a strike at Russia's Norislk plant this month and the still delayed start to Russia-Japan supply talks underpin the price, dealers said.
